whistle.text: You whistle a jaunty tune. A robin joins in, though it's clearly showing off with its superior vocal range.
Your whistling attracts the attention of a local dog walker, who assumes you're in distress and offers to call the authorities.
Harvey whistles 'Rule Britannia' with scholarly precision. The fish remain unimpressed, but a passing corgi stops to listen appreciatively.
Your whistling attempt sounds like a kettle with existential problems. Even the ducks look concerned.
Harvey whistles a complex Bach fugue from memory. A music professor walking by stops to applaud, though the fish remain stubbornly silent.

pray.text: You offer a heartfelt prayer to the gods of angling. A fish jumps nearby, which you choose to interpret as divine acknowledgment.
You pray for fishing success. The universe responds by sending a light drizzle and a family of ducks who seem to find your situation amusing.
Harvey offers a scholarly prayer to Saint Peter, patron saint of fishermen. A nearby vicar nods approvingly from the footpath.
You pray to Izaak Walton's spirit for guidance. A gentle breeze rustles the pages of your mental copy of 'The Compleat Angler.'
Harvey's prayer is interrupted by a swan who appears to be conducting its own religious service. You respectfully wait for it to finish.
You pray for patience, wisdom, and perhaps just one fish. The universe delivers on the first two, but remains mysteriously silent on the third.

curse.text: You unleash a string of creative profanity that would make a sailor blush. A nearby vicar pretends not to hear while secretly taking notes.
Your cursing is so inventive that local wildlife gathers to listen. You're pretty sure that squirrel is applauding.
Harvey unleashes a torrent of scholarly invective that would make a medieval monk proud. Several Latin phrases are involved.
You curse with the precision of a gentleman and the vocabulary of a dock worker. It's quite an impressive linguistic performance.
Harvey's cursing is so eloquent that a passing English literature student stops to take notes for their thesis on 'Creative Profanity in Rural Settings.'
You curse the fish, the river, the weather, and the fundamental laws of probability. The universe seems to take this as a personal challenge.

dance.text: You perform an interpretive dance representing the eternal struggle between angler and fish. It's surprisingly therapeutic.
Your fishing dance attracts a small crowd of bemused onlookers. Someone starts a collection, though you're not sure if it's for or against your performance.
Harvey performs a dignified morris dance, complete with imaginary handkerchiefs. A group of actual morris dancers appears and rates your performance 7/10.
You dance the ancient ritual of 'Summoning the Trout.' It's entirely made up, but performed with academic rigor.
Harvey's interpretive dance tells the story of British angling from Roman times to the present. It's a three-act performance that leaves the local wildlife genuinely moved.
You perform what can only be described as 'The Dance of Aquatic Disappointment.' It's surprisingly cathartic.

sing.text: You serenade the fish with a rousing chorus of 'Rule Britannia.' The fish remain unimpressed, but your patriotic fervor is admirable.
Your singing voice could charitably be described as 'enthusiastic.' Several fish surface, though whether from attraction or concern is unclear.
Harvey sings a traditional angling ballad he learned from his grandfather. His voice carries across the water with surprising beauty.
You sing 'Jerusalem' with such passion that a nearby church organist stops to listen. The fish, however, remain stubbornly secular.
Harvey composes and performs an original opera about the tragic love affair between an angler and an uncooperative trout. It's surprisingly moving.
You sing sea shanties to freshwater fish, which is either culturally insensitive or brilliantly innovative. The jury is still out.
Harvey's rendition of 'Greensleeves' is so haunting that a family of swans stops to listen. One appears to be weeping.

meditate.text: You achieve a state of zen-like calm, becoming one with the river. This lasts until a duck steals your sandwich.
Your meditation is interrupted by the realization that you've been sitting on an anthill. Enlightenment will have to wait.
Harvey enters a profound meditative state, contemplating the interconnectedness of all aquatic life. A heron joins him in silent contemplation.
You meditate on the teachings of Izaak Walton, achieving a state of angling enlightenment that unfortunately doesn't translate to actual fish-catching ability.
Harvey's meditation is so deep that local wildlife begins to mistake him for a particularly scholarly statue. A robin builds a nest in his hat.
You achieve perfect inner peace and understanding of the universe. Unfortunately, the universe appears to be having a laugh at your expense.

whistle_merry.text: Harvey whistles with considerably more confidence than usual! The tune is jaunty, the rhythm questionable, but the enthusiasm infectious!
Your whistling attracts not just birds, but what appears to be a small parade of woodland creatures. You're like a scholarly Snow White!

whistle_jolly.text: Harvey whistles a medley of patriotic songs while conducting an invisible orchestra! The performance is magnificent, if slightly wobbly! *hic*
Your whistling has evolved into a full musical revue! You're pretty sure that otter is keeping time! *hic*

whistle_tipsy.text: Harvey whistles the entire score of HMS Pinafore while explaining to a bemused duck why Gilbert and Sullivan revolutionized British musical theatre! *hic*

pray_merry.text: Harvey's prayers are considerably more optimistic than usual! 'Dear Lord, thank you for this magnificent day and the excellent brandy!'

pray_jolly.text: Harvey prays with such enthusiasm that he begins composing hymns on the spot! 'Oh Lord of Rivers, bless this angling endeavor!' *hic*

pray_tipsy.text: Harvey's prayers have become a theological discussion with a passing vicar about the spiritual significance of angling! The vicar seems genuinely interested! *hic*

curse_merry.text: Harvey's cursing is surprisingly cheerful! 'Blast these delightfully challenging fish!' he declares with a smile.

curse_jolly.text: Harvey curses with such creative joy that it sounds more like poetry! 'You magnificent, stubborn, aquatic scholars!' *hic*

curse_tipsy.text: Harvey's cursing has evolved into a scholarly lecture on the etymology of British profanity! A linguistics professor stops to take notes! *hic*

dance_merry.text: Harvey's dancing has considerably more flair than usual! It's still interpretive, but now with added confidence and questionable balance!

dance_jolly.text: Harvey performs what he calls 'The Brandy Ballet of Angling Triumph!' It's magnificent, ridiculous, and surprisingly athletic! *hic*

dance_tipsy.text: Harvey's interpretive dance has become a full historical reenactment of British angling! He's currently portraying the Norman Conquest of Trout! *hic*

sing_merry.text: Harvey sings with renewed vigor! His voice carries beautifully across the water, and several anglers downstream stop to listen!

sing_jolly.text: Harvey's singing has become a full concert! He's taking requests from the wildlife and dedicating songs to individual fish! *hic*

sing_tipsy.text: Harvey composes and performs an epic ballad about the heroic struggle between scholar and trout! It's twelve verses long and includes a chorus for the ducks! *hic*

meditate_merry.text: Harvey's meditation is wonderfully peaceful! He achieves a state of scholarly serenity that makes everything seem possible!

meditate_jolly.text: Harvey meditates with such enthusiasm that he begins narrating his own enlightenment! 'I am becoming one with the cosmic trout!' *hic*

meditate_tipsy.text: Harvey's meditation has become a philosophical symposium with the local wildlife! He's currently debating the nature of existence with a very patient heron! *hic*

tie_knot.text: You successfully tie what appears to be a Gordian knot. Alexander the Great would be impressed.
Your knot is perfect, but it's somehow tied around your own ankle.
You've invented a new knot that exists in four dimensions simultaneously.
Harvey ties a knot so complex that a passing mathematician stops to photograph it for their research on topology.
You successfully tie what appears to be a perfect blood knot, then realize you've attached your fly to a nearby bush instead of your line.

clean_glasses.text: Perfect! Now you can see the fish laughing at you in high definition.
Your glasses are spotless, but now everything looks like a Monet painting.
Clean glasses reveal that you've been fishing in a car park this entire time.
Harvey polishes his spectacles with scholarly precision, only to discover he's been wearing his reading glasses instead of his distance ones this entire time.
Your glasses are now so clean they've achieved a state of optical perfection that allows you to see into parallel dimensions where you're actually catching fish.

adjust_hat.text: Your hat is now perfectly positioned, but a magpie has decided it would make an excellent nest.
Hat adjusted! Though it's now facing backwards and you look like a confused rapper.
Perfect hat positioning achieved! The hat tips itself in acknowledgment.
Harvey adjusts his hat to the precise angle favored by Victorian naturalists, immediately feeling 47% more scholarly.
You adjust your hat, but it seems to have developed strong opinions about proper positioning and keeps readjusting itself.

change_fly.text: You select a Parachute Adams, but it immediately requests a parachute instructor.
Your new fly is a beautiful Royal Wulff, but it insists on being addressed as 'Your Majesty'.
You choose a Woolly Bugger, which promptly begins picking its nose.
Harvey selects a classic Blue Winged Olive, a pattern his grandfather swore by. The fly seems to approve of this traditional choice.
You change to a Greenwell's Glory, but it appears to be suffering from an identity crisis and keeps asking if it's really glorious enough.
